etymology.description: 斤 ‘a short axe’ + 廾 ‘two hands’ — a pair of hands holding a weapon; unrelated to 丘.
etymology.interpretation: Two hands grasp an axe, visually conveying armed people ready for combat. From this image, the sense extends to individual soldiers and, by extension, troops and military forces.

examples.chinese: 他年轻时当兵(他年輕時當兵)，在边境守卫(在邊境守衛)。
examples.pinyin: Tā niánqīng shí dāng bīng, zài biānjìng shǒuwèi.
examples.english: He served as a soldier when he was young and guarded the border.

examples.chinese: 敌军的兵力很强(敵軍的兵力很強)，我们必须小心应对(我們必須小心應對)。
examples.pinyin: Díjūn de bīnglì hěn qiáng, wǒmen bìxū xiǎoxīn yìngduì.
examples.english: The enemy’s troop strength is great; we must respond cautiously.

examples.chinese: 古代皇帝检阅兵马于校场(古代皇帝檢閱兵馬於校場)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔdài huángdì jiǎnyuè bīngmǎ yú xiàochǎng.
examples.english: In ancient times, emperors reviewed the troops at the drill ground.
